elements.content: A new hybrid ultramicroporous material, [Ni­(1,4-di­(pyridine-2-yl)­benzene)2(Cr2O7)] n (DICRO-4-Ni-i), has been prepared and structurally characterized. Pure gas sorption isotherms and molecular modeling of sorbate–sorbent interactions imply strong selectivity for C2H2 over CO2 (S AC). Dynamic gas breakthrough coupled with temperature-programmed desorption experiments were conducted on DICRO-4-Ni-i and two other porous materials reported to exhibit high S AC, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i and MIL-100­(Fe), using a C2H2/CO2/He (10:5:85) gas mixture. Whereas CO2/C2H2 coadsorption by MIL-100­(Fe) mitigated the purity of trapped C2H2, negligible coadsorption and high S AC were observed for DICRO-4-Ni-i and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i.
elements.clean_text: A new hybrid ultramicroporous material, [Ni(1,4-di(pyridine-2-yl)benzene)2(Cr2O7)] n  (DICRO-4-Ni-i), has been prepared and structurally characterized. Pure gas sorption isotherms and molecular modeling of sorbate-sorbent interactions imply strong selectivity for C2H2 over CO2 (S AC). Dynamic gas breakthrough coupled with temperature-programmed desorption experiments were conducted on DICRO-4-Ni-i and two other porous materials reported to exhibit high S AC, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i and MIL-100(Fe), using a C2H2/CO2/He (10:5:85) gas mixture. Whereas CO2/C2H2 coadsorption by MIL-100(Fe) mitigated the purity of trapped C2H2, negligible coadsorption and high S AC were observed for DICRO-4-Ni-i and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i.

elements.content: Acetylene is an important chemical commodity that has utility in a variety of industrial applications. Common methods used for producing C2H2 introduce contaminants, including CO2, which must later be removed. C2H2 purification using energy-efficient physisorptive separation is therefore a highly sought after goal. Recently, our group investigated an understudied class of physisorbent materials, hybrid ultramicroporous materials (HUMs), which exhibit high selectivity, including some new benchmarks for gas mixture separation performance for small polarizable gases such as C2H2 and CO2. We attribute the strong performance of such HUMs to two features likely to enhance sorbent–sorbate interactions: strong electrostatics thanks to inorganic anion pillars with strongly electronegative atoms at their periphery and ultramicropores (<0.7 nm) lined by these inorganic anions that can offer a tailored fit for important sorbates. To date, there are four families or platforms of HUMs that can be distinguished based upon the type of inorganic anion that serves as a pillar in the coordination network: MFSIX hexafluorometallate anions (e.g., SiF6 2–, TiF6 2–), mmo topology networks that incorporate angular oxyanions (e.g., CrO4 2–, MoO4 2–, and WO4 2–), MO x F6–x pillared networks comprised of anions with both O- and F atoms bound to an octahedral metal center (e.g., VOF5 2–, NbOF5 2–), and most recently, DICRO-sustained coordination networks that incorporate Cr2O7 2– anions as pillars.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Acetylene is an important chemical commodity that has utility in a variety of industrial applications. Common methods used for producing C2H2 introduce contaminants, including CO2, which must later be removed. C2H2 purification using energy-efficient physisorptive separation is therefore a highly sought after goal. Recently, our group investigated an understudied class of physisorbent materials, hybrid ultramicroporous materials (HUMs), which exhibit high selectivity, including some new benchmarks for gas mixture separation performance for small polarizable gases such as C2H2  and CO2. We attribute the strong performance of such HUMs to two features likely to enhance sorbent-sorbate interactions: strong electrostatics thanks to inorganic anion pillars with strongly electronegative atoms at their periphery and ultramicropores (<0.7 nm) lined by these inorganic anions that can offer a tailored fit for important sorbates. To date, there are four families or platforms of HUMs that can be distinguished based upon the type of inorganic anion that serves as a pillar in the coordination network: MFSIX hexafluorometallate anions (e.g., SiF6 2-, TiF6 2-), mmo topology networks that incorporate angular oxyanions (e.g., CrO4 2-, MoO4 2-, and WO4 2-), MO x F6-x  pillared networks comprised of anions with both O- and F atoms bound to an octahedral metal center (e.g., VOF5 2-, NbOF5 2-), and most recently, DICRO-sustained coordination networks that incorporate Cr2O7 2- anions as pillars.

elements.content: Here, we report the synthesis, structure, and gas sorption properties of a new member of the DICRO platform, [Ni­(1,4-di­(pyridine-2-yl)­benzene)2(Cr2O7)] n (DICRO-4-Ni-i; ). Molecular modeling identifies the location and binding energies of sorbate–sorbent interactions within the three distinct ultramicroporous channels while also confirming the significance of Cr2O7 2– orientation within the pore cavity. Dynamic gas breakthrough and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were used to determine C2H2/CO2 sorption performance of DICRO-4-Ni-i and compare it with two previously reported high-performing materials, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i and MIL-100­(Fe).
elements.clean_text: Here, we report the synthesis, structure, and gas sorption properties of a new member of the DICRO platform, [Ni(1,4-di(pyridine-2-yl)benzene)2(Cr2O7)] n  (DICRO-4-Ni-i; ). Molecular modeling identifies the location and binding energies of sorbate-sorbent interactions within the three distinct ultramicroporous channels while also confirming the significance of Cr2O7 2- orientation within the pore cavity. Dynamic gas breakthrough and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were used to determine C2H2/CO2 sorption performance of DICRO-4-Ni-i and compare it with two previously reported high-performing materials, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i and MIL-100(Fe).

is Formed via Self-Assembly of Octahedral Ni<sup>2+</sup> Centers
(light green), Organic Dipyridyl Linkers (blue), and Inorganic
Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>
<sup>2–</sup> Pillars (red) to Afford
a <bold>pcu</bold> Topology Network with a Second Identical Network
(grey) that Depicts the Two-Fold Interpenetration that Exists in DICRO-4-Ni-i</title>

elements.clean_text: 1  DICRO-4-Ni-i is Formed via Self-Assembly of Octahedral Ni2+ Centers (light green), Organic Dipyridyl Linkers (blue), and Inorganic Cr2O7 2- Pillars (red) to Afford a pcu Topology Network with a Second Identical Network (grey) that Depicts the Two-Fold Interpenetration that Exists in DICRO-4-Ni-i

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis of DICRO-4-Ni-i reveals that it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The hexacoordinate metal centers serve as six-connected (6-c) nodes: four pyridyl groups from different linker ligands (4) comprise the equatorial plane, which propagates into an sql network; the axial positions of the Ni2+ nodes coordinate to oxygen atoms from Cr2O7 2– anions (DICRO), which pillar the sql nets. The expected pcu network is thereby afforded (). Crystallographic details and selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Tables S1 and S2. Two-fold interpenetration in which the node of the second net is offset from the center of the cavity of the first net is observed. Notably, offset interpenetration results in three crystallographically distinct channels running through the structure parallel to the c-axis. These channels are present at a ratio of 4:2:2 and are labeled A, B, and C in . All three channels possess pore diameters large enough to accommodate small guest molecules, but their pore chemistries are very different because of the orientation of the inorganic pillars. The positioning of the electronegative atoms in HUMs has previously been found to strongly influence gas sorption properties, and structural analysis of the pore chemistry can thereby provide information regarding binding sites and their relative strengths. In DICRO-4-Ni-i, channel A exhibits two terminal O atoms from the Cr2O7 2– pillar (O2 and O3) that protrude into the cavity with closest O2···O3 distances of 6.17 Å; the walls of channel B contain bridging O atoms (O4) that orient toward the inside of the channel with closest O4···O4 distances of 6.57 Å. In channel C, no O atoms from Cr2O7 2– protrude into the cavity.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis of DICRO-4-Ni-i reveals that it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The hexacoordinate metal centers serve as six-connected (6-c) nodes: four pyridyl groups from different linker ligands (4) comprise the equatorial plane, which propagates into an sql network; the axial positions of the Ni2+ nodes coordinate to oxygen atoms from Cr2O7 2- anions (DICRO), which pillar the sql nets. The expected pcu network is thereby afforded (). Crystallographic details and selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Tables S1 and S2. Two-fold interpenetration in which the node of the second net is offset from the center of the cavity of the first net is observed. Notably, offset interpenetration results in three crystallographically distinct channels running through the structure parallel to the c-axis. These channels are present at a ratio of 4:2:2 and are labeled A, B, and C in . All three channels possess pore diameters large enough to accommodate small guest molecules, but their pore chemistries are very different because of the orientation of the inorganic pillars. The positioning of the electronegative atoms in HUMs has previously been found to strongly influence gas sorption properties, and structural analysis of the pore chemistry can thereby provide information regarding binding sites and their relative strengths. In DICRO-4-Ni-i, channel A exhibits two terminal O atoms from the Cr2O7 2- pillar (O2 and O3) that protrude into the cavity with closest O2⋅⋅⋅O3 distances of 6.17 Å; the walls of channel B contain bridging O atoms (O4) that orient toward the inside of the channel with closest O4⋅⋅⋅O4 distances of 6.57 Å. In channel C, no O atoms from Cr2O7 2- protrude into the cavity.

elements.content: DICRO-4-Ni-i viewed down the crystallographic c-axis. Void surfaces (probe radius of 1.2 Å) of the three distinct channels, A–C, are presented in purple and yellow. A–C occur at a frequency of 4:2:2 per unit cell. Unit cell axes are colored blue.
elements.clean_text: 1  DICRO-4-Ni-i viewed down the crystallographic c-axis. Void surfaces (probe radius of 1.2 Å) of the three distinct channels, A-C, are presented in purple and yellow. A-C occur at a frequency of 4:2:2 per unit cell. Unit cell axes are colored blue.

elements.content: Single component CO2, C2H2, and N2 sorption measurements were conducted for DICRO-4-Ni-i to determine gas uptake, ideal selectivity, and isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st). The permanent porosity of DICRO-4-Ni-i was established via N2 isotherms at 77 K (Figure S7), and the apparent BET surface area was calculated to be 398 m2/g. Under the same conditions, a pore volume of 0.22 cm3/g was calculated by assuming liquid filling of N2 at P/P 0 = 0.95, which is close to that calculated from the crystallographic data using PLATON (0.26 cm3/g). CO2 and C2H2 sorption isotherms were collected at 273, 283, and 298 K and reveal type I isotherms (Figures S8 and S9). At 298 K and 1 bar, the CO2 uptake was 23 cm3/g, whereas the C2H2 uptake was almost double that value at 43 cm3/g. The isotherms for both gases at 298 K are presented in (top left), and a summary of single component gas sorption data is given in . CO2 and C2H2 isotherms were fitted using the virial equation (Figures S10 and S12), and the isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st) was calculated using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation. Q st values at low loading for CO2 and C2H2 in DICRO-4-Ni-i were calculated to be 33.9 and 37.7 kJ/mol, respectively (, top right). Q st values for both CO2 and C2H2 in DICRO-4-Ni-i are higher than those reported in several other physisorbent materials that were studied in the context of CO2 and C2H2 separation, including ZJU-60a (15.2 and 17.6 kJ/mol), PCP-33 (26 and 27.5 kJ/mol), FJU-22a (19.5 and 23 kJ/mol), and UTSA-74 (26 and 32 kJ/mol). Selectivity for C2H2/CO2 (S AC; 1:1) gas mixtures at 298 K were calculated for DICRO-4-Ni-i using ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) after fitting isotherms to the dual-site Langmuir–Freundlich equation (see details in the Supporting Information (SI)). (bottom) reveals that C2H2/CO2 selectivities (S AC) for DICRO-4-Ni-i at 0.15 and 1.0 bar are 17.1 and 13.9, respectively. The S AC selectivity at 0.15 bar (which represents the combined proportion of CO2 and C2H2 concentrations in relevant industrial gas streams) is to our knowledge the highest reported to date. A survey of IAST-calculated selectivities in reported metal–organic materials (MOMs) at 0.15 bar and under the same gas mixture conditions reveals that DICRO-4-Ni-i has higher S AC than those of TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (6.2), HOF-3 (15), ZJU-60a (7), PCP-33 (6), MIL-100­(Fe) (12), and UTSA-74 (14.2). The CPO-27 (M/dobdc, MMOF-74) family of cylindrical channel frameworks is known to exhibit high Q st values and high uptake capacities for both CO2 and C2H2. However, this does not necessarily equate to good selectivity as indicated by UTSA-74, which is an isomer of ZnMOF-74. UTSA-74 exhibits strong interactions toward C2H2 that are in line with those of ZnMOF-74, but its interactions with CO2 are much weaker leading in turn to better S AC.
elements.clean_text: Single component CO2, C2H2, and N2 sorption measurements were conducted for DICRO-4-Ni-i to determine gas uptake, ideal selectivity, and isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st). The permanent porosity of DICRO-4-Ni-i was established via N2 isotherms at 77 K (Figure S7), and the apparent BET surface area was calculated to be 398 m2/g. Under the same conditions, a pore volume of 0.22 cm3/g was calculated by assuming liquid filling of N2 at P/P 0 = 0.95, which is close to that calculated from the crystallographic data using PLATON  (0.26 cm3/g). CO2 and C2H2 sorption isotherms were collected at 273, 283, and 298 K and reveal type I isotherms (Figures S8 and S9). At 298 K and 1 bar, the CO2 uptake was 23 cm3/g, whereas the C2H2 uptake was almost double that value at 43 cm3/g. The isotherms for both gases at 298 K are presented in  (top left), and a summary of single component gas sorption data is given in . CO2 and C2H2 isotherms were fitted using the virial equation (Figures S10 and S12), and the isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st) was calculated using the Clausius-Clapeyron equation. Q st values at low loading for CO2 and C2H2 in DICRO-4-Ni-i were calculated to be 33.9 and 37.7 kJ/mol, respectively (, top right). Q st values for both CO2 and C2H2 in DICRO-4-Ni-i are higher than those reported in several other physisorbent materials that were studied in the context of CO2 and C2H2 separation, including ZJU-60a (15.2 and 17.6 kJ/mol), PCP-33 (26 and 27.5 kJ/mol), FJU-22a (19.5 and 23 kJ/mol), and UTSA-74 (26 and 32 kJ/mol). Selectivity for C2H2/CO2 (S AC; 1:1) gas mixtures at 298 K were calculated for DICRO-4-Ni-i using ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) after fitting isotherms to the dual-site Langmuir-Freundlich equation (see details in the Supporting Information (SI)).  (bottom) reveals that C2H2/CO2 selectivities (S AC) for DICRO-4-Ni-i at 0.15 and 1.0 bar are 17.1 and 13.9, respectively. The S AC selectivity at 0.15 bar (which represents the combined proportion of CO2 and C2H2 concentrations in relevant industrial gas streams) is to our knowledge the highest reported to date. A survey of IAST-calculated selectivities in reported metal-organic materials (MOMs) at 0.15 bar and under the same gas mixture conditions reveals that DICRO-4-Ni-i has higher S AC than those of TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (6.2), HOF-3 (15), ZJU-60a (7), PCP-33 (6), MIL-100(Fe) (12), and UTSA-74 (14.2). The CPO-27 (M/dobdc, MMOF-74) family of cylindrical channel frameworks is known to exhibit high Q st values and high uptake capacities for both CO2  and C2H2. However, this does not necessarily equate to good selectivity as indicated by UTSA-74, which is an isomer of ZnMOF-74. UTSA-74 exhibits strong interactions toward C2H2 that are in line with those of ZnMOF-74, but its interactions with CO2 are much weaker leading in turn to better S AC.

elements.content: (top left) Single component gas sorption isotherms of DICRO-4-Ni-i at 298 K (CO2 = red, C2H2 = blue). Solid symbols signify adsorption, and empty symbols represent desorption measurements. (top right) Isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st) of DICRO-4-Ni-i toward CO2 and C2H2. (bottom) IAST adsorption selectivity of DICRO-4-Ni-i toward a 1:1 mixture of C2H2/CO2 at 298 K.

Summary of Gas Sorption Data for DICRO-4-Ni-i BET (m2/g) calculated micropore volume (cm3/g) experimental micropore volume (cm3/g) uptake CO2, 0.1/1 bar (cm3/g) CO2 Q st (kJ/mol) uptake C2H2, 0.1/1 bar (cm3/g) C2H2 Q st (kJ/mol) IAST, 1:1 C2H2/CO2 (0.15/1) bar DICRO-4-Ni-i 398 0.26 0.22 5/23 33.9 23/43 37.7 18.2/13.9

The accessible void space and micropore volume were calculated with the program PLATON using a probe radius of 1.2 Å.

Determined from N2 at 77 K.

At 298 K.

Molecular simulations for CO2 and C2H2 adsorption within DICRO-4-Ni-i were performed at low loading to identify sorbate–sorbent binding sites and associated energies for each of the three distinct channels and are presented in . For both sorbates, the strongest interaction is located within channel B. This is perhaps unsurprising given that the bridging atom of the dichromate pillar (O4), which protrudes into channel B, exhibits the highest electronegative character of the O atoms of the pillar and is likely to be responsible for the strong interaction energy observed (). Notably, the calculated average potential energies within channel B, equal to −28.92 and −38.04 kJ/mol for CO2 and C2H2, respectively, correspond closely to calculated Q st values (at low loading) for the respective gases (). Channel A, which contains two terminal O atoms from the Cr2O7 2– pillar (O2 and O3) protruding into the cavity, exhibits the next strongest binding site, followed by channel C, which exhibits much weaker sorbate–sorbent interactions. A detailed description of binding sites and interaction distances for each sorbate type within each channel is presented in the SI.
elements.clean_text: Molecular simulations for CO2 and C2H2 adsorption within DICRO-4-Ni-i were performed at low loading to identify sorbate-sorbent binding sites and associated energies for each of the three distinct channels and are presented in . For both sorbates, the strongest interaction is located within channel B. This is perhaps unsurprising given that the bridging atom of the dichromate pillar (O4), which protrudes into channel B, exhibits the highest electronegative character of the O atoms of the pillar and is likely to be responsible for the strong interaction energy observed (). Notably, the calculated average potential energies within channel B, equal to -28.92 and -38.04 kJ/mol for CO2 and C2H2, respectively, correspond closely to calculated Q st values (at low loading) for the respective gases (). Channel A, which contains two terminal O atoms from the Cr2O7 2- pillar (O2 and O3) protruding into the cavity, exhibits the next strongest binding site, followed by channel C, which exhibits much weaker sorbate-sorbent interactions. A detailed description of binding sites and interaction distances for each sorbate type within each channel is presented in the SI.

elements.clean_text: 3  Simulated packing of (a, b) C2H2 and (c, d) CO2 in channel B of DICRO-4-Ni-i. Sorbate molecules are presented in space-fill mode (C2H2: carbon, orange; hydrogen, white; CO2: carbon, gray; oxygen, red).

elements.content:
Calculated Average Total Potential Energies (in kJ/mol) for Single CO<sub>2</sub> and C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub> Molecules Located in the Three Distinct Channels (A–C) of DICRO-4-Ni-i As Determined from CMC Simulations at 298 K<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="tbl2-fn1"></xref> sorbate–sorbent energy (kJ/mol) channel CO2 C2H2 A –26.77 –32.44 B –28.92 –38.04 C –19.61 –25.01 Q st for DICRO-4-Ni-i –33.9 –37.7

The final entry gives the experimental isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) for CO2 and C2H2 in DICRO-4-Ni-i as calculated using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation and fitted using a virial function.

The relatively high Q st and IAST values calculated for DICRO-4-Ni-i prompted us to perform a more thorough investigation on its ability to selectively adsorb C2H2 from gas mixtures. This is because selectivity calculated through IAST relies upon fitting of data collected from single component gas isotherms, which does not always provide a realistic or reliable picture of a material’s ability to perform separations upon gas mixtures. For that reason, real-time dynamic breakthrough experiments were performed, whereby a gas mixture comprising 10% C2H2, 5% CO2, and 85% He at 1 bar was studied at 298 K; this mixture resembles the relative proportions of C2H2 and CO2 in gas streams for acetylene production. The role of He is to serve as an inert carrier gas. The sorbent was packed into a fixed-bed reactor (8 mm diameter) using ∼0.25 g sample heated to 90 °C in a flow of pure He gas until all atmospheric impurities were removed. After cooling to room temperature, the 10:5:85 C2H2/CO2/He gas mixture was passed through the sample at a flow rate of 10 cm3/min. After 10 min, complete C2H2 breakthrough occurred in DICRO-4-Ni-i, and the working capacity was calculated to be 26 cm3/g (, ), equating to a separation factor of 13. The outlet concentration of C2H2 was continuously monitored during breakthrough () using high-resolution residual gas analysis mass spectrometry (RGA-MS, with the standard error accurate to ±5 ppm) and was found to contain relatively low concentrations of C2H2 (<50 ppm), which suggests that DICRO-4-Ni-i efficiently removes C2H2 from this gas mixture.

This is because selectivity calculated through IAST relies upon fitting of data collected from single component gas isotherms, which does not always provide a realistic or reliable picture of a material's ability to perform separations upon gas mixtures. For that reason, real-time dynamic breakthrough experiments were performed, whereby a gas mixture comprising 10% C2H2, 5% CO2, and 85% He at 1 bar was studied at 298 K; this mixture resembles the relative proportions of C2H2 and CO2 in gas streams for acetylene production. The role of He is to serve as an inert carrier gas. The sorbent was packed into a fixed-bed reactor (8 mm diameter) using ~0.25 g sample heated to 90 °C in a flow of pure He gas until all atmospheric impurities were removed. After cooling to room temperature, the 10:5:85 C2H2/CO2/He gas mixture was passed through the sample at a flow rate of 10 cm3/min. After 10 min, complete C2H2 breakthrough occurred in DICRO-4-Ni-i, and the working capacity was calculated to be 26 cm3/g (, ), equating to a separation factor of 13. The outlet concentration of C2H2 was continuously monitored during breakthrough () using high-resolution residual gas analysis mass spectrometry (RGA-MS, with the standard error accurate to ±5 ppm) and was found to contain relatively low concentrations of C2H2 (<50 ppm), which suggests that DICRO-4-Ni-i efficiently removes C2H2 from this gas mixture.

Two physisorbent materials, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i6 and MIL-100­(Fe), both previously reported to exhibit selective C2H2/CO2 performance, were also synthesized and tested under the same conditions to further assess the separation performance in DICRO-4-Ni-i.
elements.clean_text: Two physisorbent materials, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i6 and MIL-100(Fe), both previously reported to exhibit selective C2H2/CO2 performance, were also synthesized and tested under the same conditions to further assess the separation performance in DICRO-4-Ni-i.

elements.content: TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, also a HUM, exhibited breakthrough results consistent with those previously reported. The working capacity of 85 cm3/g under these conditions highlights the superior uptake performance of TIFSIX-2-Cu-i when compared with that of DICRO-4-Ni-i. Interestingly, a step in the outlet concentration of C2H2 was observed before breakthrough occurs, suggestive of two binding sites for C2H2 () as previously indicated by modeling experiments.
elements.clean_text: TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, also a HUM, exhibited breakthrough results consistent with those previously reported. The working capacity of 85 cm3/g under these conditions highlights the superior uptake performance of TIFSIX-2-Cu-i when compared with that of DICRO-4-Ni-i. Interestingly, a step in the outlet concentration of C2H2 was observed before breakthrough occurs, suggestive of two binding sites for C2H2 () as previously indicated by modeling experiments.

elements.content: Breakthrough experiments for MIL-100­(Fe), a MOM containing microporous apertures and mesoporous cavities with open metal sites, revealed poor separation of C2H2/CO2 and a separation factor of 1.9. Unlike DICRO-4-Ni-i and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, the breakthrough curves for MIL-100­(Fe) reveal coadsorption during mixed gas experiments. He gas initially broke through; CO2 breakthrough occurred after 6 min, and finally, C2H2 breakthrough occurred after 12 min. Monitoring of the outlet gas mixture composition revealed C2H2 levels >50 ppm even after the first minute into the breakthrough experiment. This value fluctuated between 30 and 97 ppm until complete C2H2 breakthrough occurred ().
elements.clean_text: Breakthrough experiments for MIL-100(Fe), a MOM containing microporous apertures and mesoporous cavities with open metal sites, revealed poor separation of C2H2/CO2 and a separation factor of 1.9. Unlike DICRO-4-Ni-i and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, the breakthrough curves for MIL-100(Fe) reveal coadsorption during mixed gas experiments. He gas initially broke through; CO2 breakthrough occurred after 6 min, and finally, C2H2 breakthrough occurred after 12 min. Monitoring of the outlet gas mixture composition revealed C2H2 levels >50 ppm even after the first minute into the breakthrough experiment. This value fluctuated between 30 and 97 ppm until complete C2H2 breakthrough occurred ().

elements.content: For DICRO-4-Ni-i, TIFSIX-2-Cu-I and MIL-100­(Fe) analysis of the contents of the adsorbed phase following breakthrough was performed via TPD experiments (). Once complete breakthrough of C2H2 had occurred, the material was heated to 80 °C with evolved gases being detected using mass spectrometry. Highly pure C2H2 from the adsorbed phase was measured for both HUMs: DICRO-4-Ni-i and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i. However, despite having a lower IAST-calculated selectivity at 0.15 atm, TPD revealed a higher concentration of C2H2 in TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (99.9:0.1 C2H2/CO2) than in DICRO-4-Ni-i (98.9:1.1 C2H2/CO2). These data highlight the importance of performing experiments using gas mixtures rather than relying upon data collected from pure gas isotherms. We attribute the high concentration of trapped C2H2 in these two HUMs to the presence of ultramicropores and electronegative atoms that collectively enhance sorbate–sorbent interactions. For MIL-100­(Fe), TPD experiments revealed the contents of the adsorbed phase to constitute 70.1:29.9 C2H2/CO2. We attribute the relatively poor separation and coadsorption during breakthrough experiments to MIL-100­(Fe) lacking those structural features that promote stronger sorbate–sorbent interactions. A summary of breakthrough and TPD data for DICRO-4-Ni-i, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, and MIL-100­(Fe) is presented in and Figures S20–S25.
elements.clean_text: For DICRO-4-Ni-i, TIFSIX-2-Cu-I and MIL-100(Fe) analysis of the contents of the adsorbed phase following breakthrough was performed via TPD experiments (). Once complete breakthrough of C2H2 had occurred, the material was heated to 80 °C with evolved gases being detected using mass spectrometry. Highly pure C2H2 from the adsorbed phase was measured for both HUMs: DICRO-4-Ni-i and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i. However, despite having a lower IAST-calculated selectivity at 0.15 atm, TPD revealed a higher concentration of C2H2 in TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (99.9:0.1 C2H2/CO2) than in DICRO-4-Ni-i (98.9:1.1 C2H2/CO2). These data highlight the importance of performing experiments using gas mixtures rather than relying upon data collected from pure gas isotherms. We attribute the high concentration of trapped C2H2 in these two HUMs to the presence of ultramicropores and electronegative atoms that collectively enhance sorbate-sorbent interactions. For MIL-100(Fe), TPD experiments revealed the contents of the adsorbed phase to constitute 70.1:29.9 C2H2/CO2. We attribute the relatively poor separation and coadsorption during breakthrough experiments to MIL-100(Fe) lacking those structural features that promote stronger sorbate-sorbent interactions. A summary of breakthrough and TPD data for DICRO-4-Ni-i, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, and MIL-100(Fe) is presented in  and Figures S20-S25.

elements.content: DICRO-4-Ni-i, a new hybrid ultramicroporous material that contains three distinct channels, exhibits a high IAST-calculated selectivity for C2H2/CO2, particularly at low pressure. Molecular modeling was employed to identify the preferential binding sites and potential energies associated with the strongest sorbate–sorbent interactions within DICRO-4-Ni-i and supports the influence of pillar orientation, i.e., accessibility to electronegative atoms, in HUMs with respect to high isosteric enthalpy of adsorption and selectivity. A comparison of C2H2/CO2 separation by DICRO-4-Ni-i, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, and MIL-100­(Fe) under dynamic breakthrough conditions using a mixed gas stream of 5:10:85 CO2/C2H2/He and temperature-programmed desorption experiments reveals that both HUMs exhibit superior performance in terms of the purity of the trapping C2H2. MIL-100­(Fe), which lacks features promoting strong sorbate–sorbent interactions such as ultramicropores and electronegative atoms, exhibited C2H2/CO2 coadsorption and low selectivity under identical conditions. The incidence of coadsorption, which mitigates the purity of trapped gases, is often overlooked during mixed gas separation experiments but is likely to be an important criterion when evaluating separation performance of physisorbent materials. The high selectivity and % sorbate in the adsorbed phase for both HUM compounds, DICRO-4-Ni-i and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, provide a foundation for assessing the suitability of these materials for C2H2/CO2 separations and indicate that the ultramicroporous nature and pore chemistry of HUMs offers promise for this and related separations. However, a full understanding of the performance of a material toward a particular separation and its utility for potential applications must also involve analysis and thorough investigation of various other sorption parameters and the balance between them, including Q st, working capacity, and adsorption/desorption kinetics. These will be the subjects of future experiments involving these and related materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

DICRO-4-Ni-i, a new hybrid ultramicroporous material that contains three distinct channels, exhibits a high IAST-calculated selectivity for C2H2/CO2, particularly at low pressure. Molecular modeling was employed to identify the preferential binding sites and potential energies associated with the strongest sorbate-sorbent interactions within DICRO-4-Ni-i and supports the influence of pillar orientation, i.e., accessibility to electronegative atoms, in HUMs with respect to high isosteric enthalpy of adsorption and selectivity. A comparison of C2H2/CO2 separation by DICRO-4-Ni-i, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, and MIL-100(Fe) under dynamic breakthrough conditions using a mixed gas stream of 5:10:85 CO2/C2H2/He and temperature-programmed desorption experiments reveals that both HUMs exhibit superior performance in terms of the purity of the trapping C2H2. MIL-100(Fe), which lacks features promoting strong sorbate-sorbent interactions such as ultramicropores and electronegative atoms, exhibited C2H2/CO2 coadsorption and low selectivity under identical conditions. The incidence of coadsorption, which mitigates the purity of trapped gases, is often overlooked during mixed gas separation experiments but is likely to be an important criterion when evaluating separation performance of physisorbent materials. The high selectivity and % sorbate in the adsorbed phase for both HUM compounds, DICRO-4-Ni-i and TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, provide a foundation for assessing the suitability of these materials for C2H2/CO2 separations and indicate that the ultramicroporous nature and pore chemistry of HUMs offers promise for this and related separations. However, a full understanding of the performance of a material toward a particular separation and its utility for potential applications must also involve analysis and thorough investigation of various other sorption parameters and the balance between them, including Q st, working capacity, and adsorption/desorption kinetics. These will be the subjects of future experiments involving these and related materials.

elements.content:
Synthetic procedures, TGA, FT-IR, PXRD, single-crystal XRD, gas sorption data (including single component, breakthrough and TPD) and molecular modeling protocols. The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acsami.6b15250.

(PDF)

(CIF)

The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acsami.6b15250.  (PDF)   (CIF)

cln_elements.content:
Single component CO2, C2H2, and N2 sorption measurements were conducted for DICRO-4-Ni-i to determine gas uptake, ideal selectivity, and isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st). The permanent porosity of DICRO-4-Ni-i was established via N2 isotherms at 77 K (Figure S7), and the apparent BET surface area was calculated to be 398 m2/g. Under the same conditions, a pore volume of 0.22 cm3/g was calculated by assuming liquid filling of N2 at P/P 0 = 0.95, which is close to that calculated from the crystallographic data using PLATON (0.26 cm3/g). CO2 and C2H2 sorption isotherms were collected at 273, 283, and 298 K and reveal type I isotherms (Figures S8 and S9). At 298 K and 1 bar, the CO2 uptake was 23 cm3/g, whereas the C2H2 uptake was almost double that value at 43 cm3/g. The isotherms for both gases at 298 K are presented in (top left), and a summary of single component gas sorption data is given in . CO2 and C2H2 isotherms were fitted using the virial equation (Figures S10 and S12), and the isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st) was calculated using the Clausius–Clapeyron equation. Q st values at low loading for CO2 and C2H2 in DICRO-4-Ni-i were calculated to be 33.9 and 37.7 kJ/mol, respectively (, top right). Q st values for both CO2 and C2H2 in DICRO-4-Ni-i are higher than those reported in several other physisorbent materials that were studied in the context of CO2 and C2H2 separation, including ZJU-60a (15.2 and 17.6 kJ/mol), PCP-33 (26 and 27.5 kJ/mol), FJU-22a (19.5 and 23 kJ/mol), and UTSA-74 (26 and 32 kJ/mol). Selectivity for C2H2/CO2 (S AC; 1:1) gas mixtures at 298 K were calculated for DICRO-4-Ni-i using ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) after fitting isotherms to the dual-site Langmuir–Freundlich equation (see details in the Supporting Information (SI)). (bottom) reveals that C2H2/CO2 selectivities (S AC) for DICRO-4-Ni-i at 0.15 and 1.0 bar are 17.1 and 13.9, respectively. The S AC selectivity at 0.15 bar (which represents the combined proportion of CO2 and C2H2 concentrations in relevant industrial gas streams) is to our knowledge the highest reported to date. A survey of IAST-calculated selectivities in reported metal–organic materials (MOMs) at 0.15 bar and under the same gas mixture conditions reveals that DICRO-4-Ni-i has higher S AC than those of TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (6.2), HOF-3 (15), ZJU-60a (7), PCP-33 (6), MIL-100­(Fe) (12), and UTSA-74 (14.2). The CPO-27 (M/dobdc, MMOF-74) family of cylindrical channel frameworks is known to exhibit high Q st values and high uptake capacities for both CO2 and C2H2. However, this does not necessarily equate to good selectivity as indicated by UTSA-74, which is an isomer of ZnMOF-74. UTSA-74 exhibits strong interactions toward C2H2 that are in line with those of ZnMOF-74, but its interactions with CO2 are much weaker leading in turn to better S AC.

TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, also a HUM, exhibited breakthrough results consistent with those previously reported. The working capacity of 85 cm3/g under these conditions highlights the superior uptake performance of TIFSIX-2-Cu-i when compared with that of DICRO-4-Ni-i. Interestingly, a step in the outlet concentration of C2H2 was observed before breakthrough occurs, suggestive of two binding sites for C2H2 () as previously indicated by modeling experiments.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Single component CO2, C2H2, and N2 sorption measurements were conducted for DICRO-4-Ni-i to determine gas uptake, ideal selectivity, and isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st). The permanent porosity of DICRO-4-Ni-i was established via N2 isotherms at 77 K (Figure S7), and the apparent BET surface area was calculated to be 398 m2/g. Under the same conditions, a pore volume of 0.22 cm3/g was calculated by assuming liquid filling of N2 at P/P 0 = 0.95, which is close to that calculated from the crystallographic data using PLATON  (0.26 cm3/g). CO2 and C2H2 sorption isotherms were collected at 273, 283, and 298 K and reveal type I isotherms (Figures S8 and S9). At 298 K and 1 bar, the CO2 uptake was 23 cm3/g, whereas the C2H2 uptake was almost double that value at 43 cm3/g. The isotherms for both gases at 298 K are presented in  (top left), and a summary of single component gas sorption data is given in . CO2 and C2H2 isotherms were fitted using the virial equation (Figures S10 and S12), and the isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st) was calculated using the Clausius-Clapeyron equation. Q st values at low loading for CO2 and C2H2 in DICRO-4-Ni-i were calculated to be 33.9 and 37.7 kJ/mol, respectively (, top right). Q st values for both CO2 and C2H2 in DICRO-4-Ni-i are higher than those reported in several other physisorbent materials that were studied in the context of CO2 and C2H2 separation, including ZJU-60a (15.2 and 17.6 kJ/mol), PCP-33 (26 and 27.5 kJ/mol), FJU-22a (19.5 and 23 kJ/mol), and UTSA-74 (26 and 32 kJ/mol). Selectivity for C2H2/CO2 (S AC; 1:1) gas mixtures at 298 K were calculated for DICRO-4-Ni-i using ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) after fitting isotherms to the dual-site Langmuir-Freundlich equation (see details in the Supporting Information (SI)).  (bottom) reveals that C2H2/CO2 selectivities (S AC) for DICRO-4-Ni-i at 0.15 and 1.0 bar are 17.1 and 13.9, respectively. The S AC selectivity at 0.15 bar (which represents the combined proportion of CO2 and C2H2 concentrations in relevant industrial gas streams) is to our knowledge the highest reported to date. A survey of IAST-calculated selectivities in reported metal-organic materials (MOMs) at 0.15 bar and under the same gas mixture conditions reveals that DICRO-4-Ni-i has higher S AC than those of TIFSIX-2-Cu-i (6.2), HOF-3 (15), ZJU-60a (7), PCP-33 (6), MIL-100(Fe) (12), and UTSA-74 (14.2). The CPO-27 (M/dobdc, MMOF-74) family of cylindrical channel frameworks is known to exhibit high Q st values and high uptake capacities for both CO2  and C2H2. However, this does not necessarily equate to good selectivity as indicated by UTSA-74, which is an isomer of ZnMOF-74. UTSA-74 exhibits strong interactions toward C2H2 that are in line with those of ZnMOF-74, but its interactions with CO2 are much weaker leading in turn to better S AC.

TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, also a HUM, exhibited breakthrough results consistent with those previously reported. The working capacity of 85 cm3/g under these conditions highlights the superior uptake performance of TIFSIX-2-Cu-i when compared with that of DICRO-4-Ni-i. Interestingly, a step in the outlet concentration of C2H2 was observed before breakthrough occurs, suggestive of two binding sites for C2H2 () as previously indicated by modeling experiments.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Table 3. Summary of Breakthrough and TPD Data for DICRO-4-Ni-i, TIFSIX-2-Cu-i, and MIL-100­(Fe) for Gas Mixture 10:5:85 C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub>/CO<sub>2</sub>/He

|                    | separation factor | working capacity in cm<sup>3</sup>/g (mmol/g) | purity of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub> in the adsorbed phase (evaluated by TPD) | breakthrough time (min) at which outlet concentration exceeds 50 ppm of C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub> |
|--------------------|--------------------|----------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| DICRO-4-Ni-i        | 13                 | 26 (1.2)                                     | 98.9% C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub> (1.1% CO<sub>2</sub>)                        | 12                                                                                             |
| TIFSIX-2-Cu-i[^6]   | 50                 | 85 (3.8)                                     | 99.9% C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub> (0.1% CO<sub>2</sub>)                        | 52                                                                                             |
| MIL-100(Fe)[^24]    | 1.9                | 25 (1.1)                                     | 70.1% C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub> (29.9% CO<sub>2</sub>)                        | 0                                                                                              |

cln_elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>DICRO-4-Ni-i
is Formed via Self-Assembly of Octahedral Ni<sup>2+</sup> Centers
(light green), Organic Dipyridyl Linkers (blue), and Inorganic
Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>
<sup>2–</sup> Pillars (red) to Afford
a <bold>pcu</bold> Topology Network with a Second Identical Network
(grey) that Depicts the Two-Fold Interpenetration that Exists in DICRO-4-Ni-i</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" position="float" xlink:href="am-2016-15250p_0005.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  DICRO-4-Ni-i is Formed via Self-Assembly of Octahedral Ni2+ Centers (light green), Organic Dipyridyl Linkers (blue), and Inorganic Cr2O7 2- Pillars (red) to Afford a pcu Topology Network with a Second Identical Network (grey) that Depicts the Two-Fold Interpenetration that Exists in DICRO-4-Ni-i

cln_elements.content: DICRO-4-Ni-i viewed down the crystallographic c-axis. Void surfaces (probe radius of 1.2 Å) of the three distinct channels, A–C, are presented in purple and yellow. A–C occur at a frequency of 4:2:2 per unit cell. Unit cell axes are colored blue.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  DICRO-4-Ni-i viewed down the crystallographic c-axis. Void surfaces (probe radius of 1.2 Å) of the three distinct channels, A-C, are presented in purple and yellow. A-C occur at a frequency of 4:2:2 per unit cell. Unit cell axes are colored blue.

cln_elements.content: (top left) Single component gas sorption isotherms of DICRO-4-Ni-i at 298 K (CO2 = red, C2H2 = blue). Solid symbols signify adsorption, and empty symbols represent desorption measurements. (top right) Isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st) of DICRO-4-Ni-i toward CO2 and C2H2. (bottom) IAST adsorption selectivity of DICRO-4-Ni-i toward a 1:1 mixture of C2H2/CO2 at 298 K.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (top left) Single component gas sorption isotherms of DICRO-4-Ni-i at 298 K (CO2 = red, C2H2 = blue). Solid symbols signify adsorption, and empty symbols represent desorption measurements. (top right) Isosteric enthalpy of adsorption (Q st) of DICRO-4-Ni-i toward CO2 and C2H2. (bottom) IAST adsorption selectivity of DICRO-4-Ni-i toward a 1:1 mixture of C2H2/CO2 at 298 K.

cln_elements.content: Simulated packing of (a, b) C2H2 and (c, d) CO2 in channel B of DICRO-4-Ni-i. Sorbate molecules are presented in space-fill mode (C2H2: carbon, orange; hydrogen, white; CO2: carbon, gray; oxygen, red).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Simulated packing of (a, b) C2H2 and (c, d) CO2 in channel B of DICRO-4-Ni-i. Sorbate molecules are presented in space-fill mode (C2H2: carbon, orange; hydrogen, white; CO2: carbon, gray; oxygen, red).

cln_elements.content: (left) Concentration of C2H2 in outlet gas stream until breakthrough occurs. Solid symbols indicate the average uptake before breakthrough. (right) Proportion and identity of sorbate (C2H2 and CO2) released in temperature-programmed desorption experiments following breakthrough.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (left) Concentration of C2H2 in outlet gas stream until breakthrough occurs. Solid symbols indicate the average uptake before breakthrough. (right) Proportion and identity of sorbate (C2H2 and CO2) released in temperature-programmed desorption experiments following breakthrough.

metadata.title:
Highly Selective Separation of C2H2 from CO2 by a New Dichromate-Based Hybrid Ultramicroporous
Material
